summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Paul A. Engelmayer regarding a FOIA lawsuit brought by The New York Times Company against the Federal Bureau of Prisons. The letter accompanies the government's first in-camera production of records related to Jeffrey Epstein, explains the redaction system used, and notes that many emails involving Tartaglione's defense counsel were collected due to the law firm's name containing 'Epstein' but may not be responsive to the Times's request.

persons.name: Paul A. Engelmayer
persons.context: The judge presiding over the FOIA case The New York Times Co. v. Federal Bureau of Prisons. The letter is addressed to him.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The FOIA action seeks records related to him. His name appears in email signature blocks of Tartaglione's defense counsel due to the law firm's name.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: Defendant in United States v. Tartaglione (16-cr-832). Emails between his defense counsel and BOP regarding his confinement conditions are part of the production, withheld under Exemption 7(A).

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: Defendant in United States v. Noel (19-cr-830). Records withheld under FOIA Exemption 7(A) are based on this case.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Tartaglione's defense counsel. Emails between him and BOP are included in the production because his law firm's name contains 'Epstein' in its signature block.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who signed the submission letter.

persons.name: Steven J. Kochevar
persons.context: Assistant U.S. Attorney who authored and signed the letter on behalf of the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Christenson
persons.context: Referenced in 'supplemental Christenson declaration' regarding records identified in Exhibit 1.

connections.description: Bruce Barket is identified as Tartaglione's defense counsel. Emails between Barket and BOP discuss Tartaglione's confinement conditions.
Barket's law firm is named Barket, Epstein, Kearon, Aldea & LoTurco, LLP, so the name 'Epstein' appears in his email signature block, leading to collection of his emails in the FOIA search.
Kochevar is an Assistant U.S. Attorney acting on behalf of United States Attorney Audrey Strauss in submitting this letter and production to the court.

events.title: Government's First In-Camera Production Submission
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office submits its first in-camera production of 986 pages of records to Judge Engelmayer in the FOIA case The New York Times Co. v. Federal Bureau of Prisons.

locations: 86 Chambers Street, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government produced 986 pages of records (375 pages of non-email documents and 611 pages of emails) to the court in response to a FOIA request by The New York Times for records related to Jeffrey Epstein.

Many emails between Tartaglione's defense counsel Bruce Barket and the BOP were collected because the law firm's name 'Barket, Epstein, Kearon, Aldea & LoTurco, LLP' includes 'Epstein' in its signature block, causing it to be captured by electronic search terms.

The government used a detailed color-coded highlighting system to indicate redactions based on specific FOIA exemptions (e.g., red for Exemption 7(A) based on United States v. Noel, goldenrod yellow for Exemption 7(A) based on United States v. Tartaglione).
The government suggests that emails regarding Tartaglione's confinement conditions, while withheld, may not be directly responsive to the Times's FOIA request about Jeffrey Epstein.
